images.altText: Stylized image of beakers, flasks, test tubes, and the periodic table

pageData.text: In this investigation, students will use basic scientific measuring equipment to determine the <button class='glossary-text'>accuracy</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>uncertainty</button> associated with measurements using common laboratory glassware.

pageData.altText:
Preparation: 5 minutes,
Activity 1: Determination of Uncertainty in Lab Balance: 20 minutes,
Activity 2: Determination of Uncertainty in Common Glassware: 60 minutes,
Activity 3: Determination of Accuracy in Common Glassware: 40 minutes
pageData.title: Time Requirements

text: Determine the <button class='glossary-text'>uncertainty</button> of measurements with standard glassware and equipment.
Determine the <button class='glossary-text'>accuracy</button> of measurements with standard glassware.

pageData.subTitle: Personal protective equipment (PPE)
pageData.altText: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol

pageData.subTitle: Protocol symbols
pageData.altText: video link symbol, camera symbol, stopwatch symbol

pageData.subTitle: Hazard pictograms
pageData.altText: warning symbol, corrosion symbol, flammable symbol, toxic symbol, environment symbol, health hazard symbol

pageData.text: Communication is paramount in the scientific community because reproducibility is what establishes the theories and laws we recognize within the various scientific disciplines. If presented theories cannot be reproduced by scientists across the globe, they will not be confirmed. And scientists cannot reproduce an experiment if the conditions, procedures, and results are not clearly communicated via terminology every scientist understands. The General Conference on Weights and Measures began creating a common language among scientists when they defined the International System of Units, abbreviated SI (from the French Le Systeme International d'Unites). You can consider the SI system as the modern form of the metric system. The SI system is the only system of measurement that is officially recognized in nearly every country in the world. When reporting measurements, <button class='glossary-text'>significant figures</button> complement the SI units by allowing scientists to recognize how precise a reported answer is, or how much <button class='glossary-text'>uncertainty</button> there is within reported results. This also allows scientists to immediately gauge whether their equipment is capable of accurately reproducing the reported values of an experiment.

pageData.altText: Five scientists in lab coats posing as if in the middle of a discussion in a laboratory setting.

pageData.text: Measurements can come in many forms, such as length, weight (mass), volume and temperature, but there are many other forms you may encounter in the future. This investigation will focus on two: how to measure weight and volume, and some common equipment used to measure both.

pageData.subTitle: Using Your Scale
pageData.text: To measure the weight of an object (more scientifically referred to as the mass) a scale or balance is used. Your lab kit contains a small scale that will be used to weigh all substances in your course. Within the box your scale arrives in are two AAA batteries and the balance with a lid. When you remove the lid, there are complete instructions on the use of the scale on the inside. When looking at the top of the scale, there are 5 points of interest. First is the pan, this is the large, flat surface above the LCD screen. Objects you wish to weigh are placed on the pan. Below the pan is the LCD screen. This is where the mass of an object on the pan will be displayed. Below the screen are three buttons reading, from left to right, ON/OFF, MODE, and TARE. When you first turn on the balance by pressing the ON/OFF button the screen should read 0.00 g (g stands for grams in this instance).

This indicates there is no mass on the balance. If the letter at the end is not g, you can press the MODE button until “g” is listed as the units. If the screen is not indicating a mass of 0.00, you can press the TARE button to re-zero the scale. After you press the TARE button, the scale should reset to 0.00 g. The scale has a maximum capacity of 100 g; if a mass greater than 100 g is placed on the pan, the screen will read “0_Ld,” indicating too large a mass has been placed on the pan.

pageData.subTitle: Measuring Liquids
pageData.text: To measure a volume of liquid, typically a piece of glassware, such as a beaker or graduated cylinder, is used. The equipment is placed on a flat countertop or table, and liquid is poured into it. The bottom of the meniscus (the concave layer or water at the top) is where the volume is measured against the scale <button class='resource-text'>(Figure 1)</button>. As you will see in Activity 2, the volume you read from a particular piece of glassware may be at best an estimate. Having measurable results is an integral part of the scientific method. Scientists must contend with two main factors while taking measurements: the <button class='glossary-text'>accuracy</button> of the measurement and the <button class='glossary-text'>precision</button> of the measurement. Accuracy is how close a set of data is to the actual value. 'Accuracy is gauged by comparing the measured value of a known standard to its true value'.Ignore color of text. Precision refers to how close a data point is to other measurements in a data set.

A data set that is accurate is not necessarily precise, whereas a very precise data set could be highly inaccurate. Forces that affect the <button class='glossary-text'>accuracy</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>precision</button> in measurements are <button class='glossary-text'>error</button>. In scientific settings, error is defined as the difference between the measured value and the actual value, where the actual value is a known value, sometimes referred to as a standard. Two main types of error exist: systematic and random.

pageData.altText: Figure 1: Diagram showing a close up of reading a meniscus.

pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Systematic error</button> is a type of error that causes measurements to be inaccurate by a certain value in a particular direction. Systematic error can be further divided into absolute and <button class='glossary-text'>relative error</button>. <button class='glossary-text'>Absolute error</button> has both magnitude and direction and is represented as a discrete value. For example, if your alarm clock is slow by five minutes it has a systematic, absolute error. Each morning you will be getting up five minutes later than planned and dealing with the potential repercussions. Absolute error can be calculated as follows:

absolute error = |measurement - actual value|
absolute error = |6:35 - 6:40| = 5 minutes
The || brackets indicate that you take the absolute value of a calculation. An absolute value means the value in the bracket will always be positive.

There is a second type of systematic error called relative error, or percent error, which is expressed as a percentage. One of the more common measuring devices with built-in percent error is the speedometer of a car. Most automobile manufacturers have a tolerance of ±2% in their speedometers.

This means that any given speedometer could read between 2% too slow or 2% too fast. If your speedometer reads 61 mph, while actually traveling 60 mph, the percent <button class='glossary-text'>error</button> is calculated using the equation below.
= |measurement - actual value|/actual value x 100%
relative error = |61 mph - 60 mph|/60 mph x 100% = 1.6%

Related to relative error is the concept of percent error. Percent error is calculated by comparing a measurement against an accepted value. Typically an accepted value is measured with a high level of and , but it is still a measured value—no matter what, there is always some form of error associated with a measured value.
percent error = |measurement - accepted value|/accepted value x 100%

An important characteristic of <button class='glossary-text'>systematic error</button>, both absolute and relative, is that it can be either corrected or accounted for in future measurements as it has both direction and magnitude. With your alarm clock, you could change the time so that it is no longer 5 minutes fast; with the speedometer you could mathematically correct for the relative error in future readings.

Although systematic error can be corrected for if discovered, <button class='glossary-text'>random error</button> will be present in all measurements. Through improved experimental design and best lab practices, random error can be reduced but it can never be eliminated. The most common form of random error in a lab setting comes from the equipment. This type of random error is most commonly referred to as <button class='glossary-text'>uncertainty</button>. Uncertainty is the limit of quantifiable measurement with confidence using measuring equipment.

pageData.question: Most automobile manufacturers have a tolerance of ±2% in their speedometers. Which of the following best describes the meaning of this tolerance?

options.text: The car’s actual speed could be 2 percent faster than the speedometer’s displayed speed.
The car’s actual speed could be 20 times faster than the speedometer’s displayed speed.
The car’s actual speed could be 2 times slower than the speedometer’s displayed speed.
The car’s actual speed could be 2 mph slower than the speedometer's displayed speed.
The car’s actual speed could be 20 mph faster than the speedometer’s displayed speed.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: A tolerance of ±2% means that any given speedometer could read between 2% too slow or 2% too fast.

pageData.question: A scale at the gym displays your weight as 149 lbs when your actual weight is 150 lbs. What type of error is this?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The scale at the gym being off by 1 lb is an example of absolute error.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body:
Systematic error is a type of error that causes measurements to be inaccurate by a certain value in a particular direction. Systematic error can be further divided into absolute and relative error. Absolute error has both magnitude and direction and is represented as a discrete value. For example, if your alarm clock is slow by five minutes it has a systematic, absolute error. Each morning you will be getting up five minutes later than planned and dealing with the potential repercussions. Relative error, or percent error, is expressed as a percentage. One of the more common measuring devices with built-in percent error is the speedometer of a car. Most automobile manufacturers have a tolerance of ±2% in their speedometers. This means that any given speedometer could read between 2% too slow or 2% too fast. relative error = |measurement - actual value|/actual value x 100%
relative error = |61 mph - 60 mph|/60 mph x 100% = 1.6%

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body:
Systematic error is a type of error that causes measurements to be inaccurate by a certain value in a particular direction. Systematic error can be further divided into absolute and relative error. Absolute error has both magnitude and direction and is represented as a discrete value. For example, if your alarm clock is slow by five minutes it has a systematic, absolute error. Each morning you will be getting up five minutes later than planned and dealing with the potential repercussions. Relative error, or percent error, is expressed as a percentage. One of the more common measuring devices with built-in percent error is the speedometer of a car. Most automobile manufacturers have a tolerance of ±2% in their speedometers. This means that any given speedometer could read between 2% too slow or 2% too fast. relative error = |measurement - actual value|/actual value x 100%

pageData.text:
One method for determining the of an analog measuring device is to utilize the scale provided on the equipment. For example, on the 10-mL graduated cylinder , there are graduations (lines) every 0.1 mL.
In Figure 1, the bottom of the meniscus is between the graduations of 6.7 and 6.8. Most people would read the volume as 6.75 mL. You can say with certainty that the water is between 6.70 and 6.80 mL, but many people would have difficulty determining a finer range of certainty.
A simple method for determining the measured value and the uncertainty is as follows:

measured value = high interval + low interval/2
6.75 = 6.80 + 6.70/2
Uncertainty = high interval - low interval/2
0.05 = 6.80 - 6.70/2
The measured value in this example would be 6.75 mL ± 0.05 mL.

The ±0.05 mL indicates confidence that the actual value for this measurement is  between 6.80 mL and 6.70 mL. With a digital device, such as the balance supplied in your equipment kit, uncertainty is generally limited to the last significant figure. For example, a balance that can read to tenths of a gram would have an uncertainty in the tenth’s place, typically of ±0.1 or ±0.2 grams. Uncertainty is generally calculated using a standard and a high number of measurements. A standard is a chemical or piece of equipment that has a known quantity associated with it, in this case a mass. For this activity, plastic cups are used as your standard for determining the uncertainty in your balance.

<button class='glossary-text'>Error</button>, uncertainty, and equipment segue into the mathematical concept of <button class='glossary-text'>significant figures</button>. Significant figures are digits relating to the <button class='glossary-text'>precision</button> of measurement. There are some general rules for determining if a digit is significant:

text: All non-zero digits are considered significant.
Zeros appearing anywhere between two non-zero digits are significant (0.1003 has 4 <button class='glossary-text'>significant figures</button>).
Leading zeros are not significant (0.0076 has 2 significant figures).
Trailing zeros in a number containing a decimal point are significant. For example, 35.000 has five significant figures.

pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Uncertainty</button> limits the <button class='glossary-text'>precision</button> and the number of significant figures in a measurement. In the example above, the 6.75 mL of water in the graduated cylinder has three significant figures. The 6 before the decimal and the 7 and 5 after the decimal are all considered significant. This is confirmed with the uncertainty of 0.05 mL. In this instance the uncertainty indicates that there are no additional significant figures beyond the hundredths place. However, if the graduated cylinder was measured at 6.75, but the uncertainty was determined to be 0.20 mL.
The number of significant figures would be limited to two, and the measurement would be reported as 6.8 mL ± 0.2 mL.

In the next example, let’s assume that the volume measurement above had a of 1%.
6.75mL x 1%/100% = 0.0675mL

This would equate to an <button class='glossary-text'>absolute error</button> of .0675 mL in the measurement. Like 6.75 mL, .0675 mL has three significant figures. However, the process of multiplication and division has added a false precision to the result. 6.75 mL ± 0.0675 mL is incorrect because the calculated <button class='glossary-text'>error</button> has additional precision that the original measurement can contain. In this instance the proper measured value would be written as 6.75 mL ± 0.07 mL. In general, you cannot gain significant figures and you cannot gain precision in a measurement through mathematical functions.

pageData.question: What is one way to reduce uncertainty when using analog measuring equipment?

options.text: Use the scale provided on the equipment.
Guess at whatever number you want.
If only two numbers are reported on a scale, estimate what the next three numbers would be.
There is no way to reduce uncertainty.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: If the bottom of the meniscus is between the graduations of 6.7 and 6.8. Most people would read the volume as 6.75 mL. You can say with certainty, based on the scale, that the water is between 6.70 and 6.80 mL, but many people would have difficulty determining a finer range of certainty.

pageData.question: A balance that can read to what degree typically has an uncertainty of ±0.1 or ±0.2 grams?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: A balance that can read to tenths of a gram would have an uncertainty in the tenth’s place, typically of ±0.1 or ±0.2 grams.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Although systematic error can be corrected for if discovered, random error will be present in all measurements. Through improved experimental design and best lab practices, random error can be reduced but it can never be eliminated. The most common form of random error in a lab setting comes from the equipment. This type of random error is most commonly referred to as uncertainty. Uncertainty is the limit of quantifiable measurement with confidence using measuring equipment. One method for determining the uncertainty of an analog measuring device is to utilize the scale provided on the equipment. For example, on the 10-mL graduated cylinder below, there are graduations (lines) every 0.1 mL. With a digital device, such as the balance supplied in your equipment kit, uncertainty is generally limited to the last significant figure.

pageData.desc: This map describes the workflow for this investigation. In Activity 1, you will take the mass of two different plastic cups; you will take five readings per cup. Then, you will determine the average mass of each cup, the deviation from the average for each trial, and the deviation from the average for each cup. In Activity 2, you will take volume measurements using four different glassware items. For each item, you will measure its mass, add a target volume of water to the item, record the highest and lowest volume intervals, calculate uncertainty, and measure the mass of the item with its water. Once all the glassware items have been tested, you will calculate the mass of the water within each item. In Activity 3, you will use the current room temperature to calculate the volumes of water from Activity 2. Finally, you will compare the measured volumes against the calculated volumes.
pageData.altText: This map describes the workflow for this investigation. In Activity 1, you will take the mass of two different plastic cups; you will take five readings per cup. Then, you will determine the average mass of each cup, the deviation from the average for each trial, and the deviation from the average for each cup. In Activity 2, you will take volume measurements using four different glassware items. For each item, you will measure its mass, add a target volume of water to the item, record the highest and lowest volume intervals, calculate uncertainty, and measure the mass of the item with its water. Once all the glassware items have been tested, you will calculate the mass of the water within each item. In Activity 3, you will use the current room temperature to calculate the volumes of water from Activity 2. Finally, you will compare the measured volumes against the calculated volumes.

Safety goggles should be worn during this investigation. There are no additional safety concerns.

Read all the instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE) described in the Safety and Procedure section.

Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this activity. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing the activity. Clean up the work area with soap and water after completing the investigation. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span className=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following best describes an object of known mass that can be used to establish uncertainty in measurements made with a balance?
The mass of a wooden block is reported to be 5.20 g ± 0.05 g. What does the “0.05 g” indicate about the measurement?

Charlie is a chemistry student conducting an experiment at home, as approved by his professor. Despite attempts to eliminate sources of experimental error from his design, Charlie still finds his results have measurable uncertainty. Which of the following statements from Charlie’s professor best explains the results?

options.text: There is no way to eliminate all uncertainty.
The only way to eliminate all uncertainty is to use the best equipment possible.
Uncertainty can be eliminated if you have a lab partner replicate the results.
Uncertainty can be eliminated if all the equipment is properly cleaned.
The only way to eliminate uncertainty is to perform experiments in a formal lab setting.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following statements about significant figures is correct?

options.text: They are digits that describe the accuracy of measurement.
Trailing zeroes in a number containing a decimal point are insignificant.
The number of significant figures in a measurement is determined experimentally.

assestmentData.question: How many significant figures are in the number 9641.25?
How many significant figures are in the number 0.08546000?
Which of the following refers to how close data are to their actual values?
An object known to be 20 mm in length is measured as 18 mm in length. What is the percent error?

The Erlenmeyer flask and thermometer used in this investigation are made of glass. In the event an item breaks, which of the following steps should be taken to dispose of the glass in the household trash?

options.text: Use a broom and dustpan to collect the glass in a hard-sided container before disposal.
Use a broom and dustpan to collect the glass for disposal directly into the trash.
Use gloved hands to collect the glass into a hard-sided container before disposal.
Use bare hands to collect the glass into a hard-sided container before disposal.
Use gloved hands to collect the glass for disposal directly into the trash.

You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Read procedure thoroughly.
Locate and clean work area.
Gather all needed materials.
In Activity 1, you will determine the <button class='glossary-text'>uncertainty</button> in your electronic balance by measuring the mass of two different plastic cups.

pages.pageTitle:
A
 Determination of Uncertainty in Lab Balance (11 steps)
pages.title:
A
 Determination of Uncertainty in Lab Balance (11 steps)

pageData.text: Turn on your balance and allow the reading to stabilize at 0.00. If the balance does not read 0.00, press the tare button.
Label two plastic cups as plastic cup #1 and plastic cup #2.
Place your first plastic cup on the balance and record the mass in Data Table 1.
Remove the cup from the balance and allow the balance to restabilize at 0.00.
Repeat steps 3 and 4 for four additional readings
Place your second plastic cup on the balance and record the mass in Data Table 1.
Remove the cup from the balance and allow the balance to restabilize at 0.00.
Repeat steps 6 and 7 for four additional readings.
Determine the average mass of each cup and record the value in Data Table 1.
For each trial perform the following calculation:
deviation from average = |average mass of cup - mass of cup in trial|
Determine the average “deviation from average” for each cup. This is the <button class='glossary-text'>uncertainty</button> of your measurement with the balance.
In Activity 2, you will determine the <button class='glossary-text'>uncertainty</button> of four different pieces of glassware by using each to measure a target volume of water.

pages.title:
B
 Determination of Uncertainty in Common Glassware (10 steps)
pages.pageTitle:
B
 Determination of Uncertainty in Common Glassware (10 steps)

pageData.text: Turn on your balance and allow the reading to stabilize at 0.00. If the balance does not read 0.00, press the tare button.
Place the 10-mL graduated cylinder on the balance and record the mass in Data Table 2.
Remove the graduated cylinder from the balance.
Add approximately 7 mL of water to the 10-mL graduated cylinder
Record the volume of water in Data Table 2 based on the meniscus of the water. For some pieces of glassware this may be an estimate.

Record the highest and lowest volume interval in Data Table 2. These should be volumes that you are certain the actual volume is between. Use the graduations (lines) on the glassware to help determine the higher and lower interval.
Calculate the <button class='glossary-text'>uncertainty</button> of your measurement.
Uncertainty = (high volume interval - low volume interval)/2
Zero the balance and record the mass of the graduated cylinder with water in Data Table 2.
Repeat steps 1–8 with each remaining glassware. Use the target volumes listed in Table 1 for step 4.
Calculate the mass of water in each piece of glassware and record the mass in Data Tables 2 and 3.
Mass of water = Mass of glassware with water – Mass of empty glassware

In Activity 3, you will calculate the actual volumes of water from Activity 2 and compare these values to the experimental values to determine the <button class='glossary-text'>accuracy</button> of each piece of glassware.

pages.title:
C
 Determination of Accuracy in Common Glassware (03 steps)
pages.pageTitle:
C
 Determination of Accuracy in Common Glassware (03 steps)

pageData.text: Using the thermometer, record the current room temperature in Data Table 3. For simplicity, you will assume that the water used in Activity 2 was at this room temperature.
Using Table 2 below, record the density of water at the current room temperature in Data Table 3.

tableData.text: How to use this table: If the water temperature is 23.4 °C: Start at the 23 °C row and go over to the “g/mL + 0.4 °C” column. The density at 23.4 °C would be 0.9974 g/mL.
tableData.hoverText: How to use this table: If the water temperature is 23.4 °C: Start at the 23 °C row and go over to the “g/mL + 0.4 °C” column. The density at 23.4 °C would be 0.9974 g/mL.

pageData.text: Calculate the volume of water from Activity 2 for each piece of glassware and record in Data Table 3.
Reminder: volume = mass/density
Rinse and dry the lab equipment and return the materials to your equipment kit.
You have reached the end of the investigation. Follow your instructors directions to submit this assignment.
pageData.confirmationMessage: Are you sure you want to submit your work? You will not be able to edit the lab notebook after submitting your work.

data.title: Absolute error
data.content: Has both magnitude and direction and is represented as a discrete value

data.title: Accuracy
data.content: Is gauged by comparing the measured value of a known standard to its true value

data.title: Error
data.content: Error is defined as the difference between the measured value and the actual value, where the actual value is a known value, sometimes referred to as a standard

data.title: Precision
data.content: Refers to how close a data point is to other measurements in a data set

data.title: Random error
data.content: Will be present in all measurements

data.title: Significant figures
data.content: Digits relating to the precision of measurement

data.title: Systematic error
data.content: A type of error that causes measurements to be inaccurate by a certain value in a particular direction

data.title: Uncertainty
data.content: The limit of quantifiable measurement with confidence using measuring equipment
